issue.title: tests: add testing for Python 3.14 Pre-release

issue.body:
Fixes #2239

BEGIN_COMMIT_OVERRIDE

rename.from: bug(Python): `RuntimeError: no running event loop` when using Python 3.14.0a7
rename.to: bug(Python): `RuntimeError: no running event loop` when using Python 3.14.0b1

body:
Some differences between 3.13 and 3.14


- In 3.14, ` asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()` now raises `RuntimeError: There is no current event loop in thread 'MainThread'` because there is no event loop
- In 3.14, `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy()` emits deprecation warning `DeprecationWarning: 'asyncio.get_event_loop_policy' is deprecated and slated for removal in Python 3.16`

The code below could be changed to swallow the `DeprecationWarning: There is no current event loop` which appears in Python 3.12/3.13 without treating all deprecation warnings as errors. We also need to handle the new `RuntimeError` when there is no event loop when calling  `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()`

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/116820911e0a0775f3e1be92a6e0896d0c0d61d4/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi#L186-L194


Testing: 

```
python3.14
Python 3.14.0b1 (main, May  7 2025, 19:23:10) [GCC 14.2.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import asyncio
>>> asyncio.get_running_loop()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<python-input-1>", line 1, in <module>
    asyncio.get_running_loop()
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^
RuntimeError: no running event loop
>>> asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()
<python-input-2>:1: DeprecationWarning: 'asyncio.get_event_loop_policy' is deprecated and slated for removal in Python 3.16
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<python-input-2>", line 1, in <module>
    asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.14/asyncio/events.py", line 718, in get_event_loop
    raise RuntimeError('There is no current event loop in thread %r.'
                       % threading.current_thread().name)
RuntimeError: There is no current event loop in thread 'MainThread'.
>>> asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().new_event_loop()
<python-input-3>:1: DeprecationWarning: 'asyncio.get_event_loop_policy' is deprecated and slated for removal in Python 3.16
<_UnixSelectorEventLoop running=False closed=False debug=False>
>>> exit()
```

```
(py3131) partheniou@partheniou-vm-3:~$ python3
Python 3.13.1 (main, Apr  7 2025, 22:14:29) [GCC 14.2.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import asyncio
>>> asyncio.get_running_loop()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<python-input-1>", line 1, in <module>
    asyncio.get_running_loop()
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^
RuntimeError: no running event loop
>>> asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()
<python-input-2>:1: DeprecationWarning: There is no current event loop
  asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()
<_UnixSelectorEventLoop running=False closed=False debug=False>
>>> asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().new_event_loop()
<_UnixSelectorEventLoop running=False closed=False debug=False>
>>> 

```

We would still need to migrate off `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy()` prior to Python 3.16 as stated by the deprecation warning. I'll file a separate issue for that.

issue.title: [Python] `PythonFinalizationError: cannot join thread at interpreter shutdown` when using Python 3.14 with workaround

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
<!--
PLEASE DO NOT POST A QUESTION HERE.
This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY!

For general questions and troubleshooting, please ask/look for answers at StackOverflow, with "grpc" tag: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/grpc

For questions that specifically need to be answered by gRPC team members, please ask/look for answers at grpc.io mailing list: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/grpc-io

Issues specific to *grpc-java*, *grpc-go*, *grpc-node*, *grpc-dart*, *grpc-web* should be created in the repository they belong to (e.g. https://github.com/grpc/grpc-LANGUAGE/issues/new)
-->

### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
gRPC at HEAD
Python

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
Linux (ubuntu, rodete)

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
Python 3.14.0b1
gcc version 14.2.0 (Debian 14.2.0-19+build4)

### What did you do?
Please provide either 1) A unit test for reproducing the bug or 2) Specific steps for us to follow to reproduce the bug. If there’s not enough information to debug the problem, gRPC team may close the issue at their discretion. You’re welcome to re-open the issue once you have a reproduction.

I made the following change to gRPC code to attempt to resolve https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/39507

```diff
partheniou@partheniou-vm-3:~/git/grpc$ git diff src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi
diff --git a/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi b/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi
index 0e3e8de00b..674539bdac 100644
--- a/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi
+++ b/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi
@@ -183,14 +183,25 @@ if PY_MAJOR_VERSION >= 3 and PY_MINOR_VERSION >= 7:
         try:
             return asyncio.get_running_loop()
         except RuntimeError:
-            with warnings.catch_warnings():
-                # Convert DeprecationWarning to errors so we can capture them with except
-                warnings.simplefilter("error", DeprecationWarning)
                 try:
-                    return asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()
-                # Since version 3.12, DeprecationWarning is emitted if there is no
+                    with warnings.catch_warnings():
+                        # For `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()`:
+                        #
+                        # - Since Python 3.12, `DeprecationWarning` is emitted if there
+                        #   is no current event loop.
+                        # - Since Python 3.14, `DeprecationWarning` for
+                        #   `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy()` also appears.
+                        #
+                        # In the interim, silence all `DeprecationWarning` for
+                        # `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()`
+                        warnings.simplefilter("ignore", category=DeprecationWarning)
+                        return asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()
+                # Since version 3.14, `RuntimeError` is emitted if there is no
                 # current event loop.
-                except DeprecationWarning:
+                except RuntimeError:
+                    # TODO(https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/39518):
+                    # Migrate off of `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy()`
+                    # prior to official launch of Python 3.14.
                     return asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().new_event_loop()
```


The workaround allow me to use Python 3.14. Previously Python 3.14  was blocked without this workaround. When I exited the interpreter, I encountered error `PythonFinalizationError: cannot join thread at interpreter shutdown`. 

```
partheniou@partheniou-vm-3:~/git/grpc$ python3.14
Python 3.14.0b1 (main, May  7 2025, 19:23:10) [GCC 14.2.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import grpc
>>> from grpc import aio
>>> print(grpc.__version__)
1.73.0.dev100 # this is my own debug version
>>> aio.secure_channel("http://localhost/", grpc.local_channel_credentials())
<grpc.aio._channel.Channel object at 0x7f102cd7b770>
>>> exit()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/grpc_aio.pyx.pxi", line 110, in grpc._cython.cygrpc.shutdown_grpc_aio
    with _global_aio_state.lock:
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/grpc_aio.pyx.pxi", line 114, in grpc._cython.cygrpc.shutdown_grpc_aio
    _actual_aio_shutdown()
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/grpc_aio.pyx.pxi", line 79, in grpc._cython.cygrpc._actual_aio_shutdown
    (<PollerCompletionQueue>_global_aio_state.cq).shutdown()
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/completion_queue.pyx.pxi", line 136, in grpc._cython.cygrpc.PollerCompletionQueue.shutdown
    self._poller_thread.join(timeout=_POLL_AWAKE_INTERVAL_S)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.14/threading.py", line 1130, in join
    self._os_thread_handle.join(timeout)
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^
PythonFinalizationError: cannot join thread at interpreter shutdown
Exception ignored in: 'grpc._cython.cygrpc.AioChannel.__dealloc__'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/grpc_aio.pyx.pxi", line 110, in grpc._cython.cygrpc.shutdown_grpc_aio
    with _global_aio_state.lock:
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/grpc_aio.pyx.pxi", line 114, in grpc._cython.cygrpc.shutdown_grpc_aio
    _actual_aio_shutdown()
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/grpc_aio.pyx.pxi", line 79, in grpc._cython.cygrpc._actual_aio_shutdown
    (<PollerCompletionQueue>_global_aio_state.cq).shutdown()
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/completion_queue.pyx.pxi", line 136, in grpc._cython.cygrpc.PollerCompletionQueue.shutdown
    self._poller_thread.join(timeout=_POLL_AWAKE_INTERVAL_S)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.14/threading.py", line 1130, in join
    self._os_thread_handle.join(timeout)
PythonFinalizationError: cannot join thread at interpreter shutdown
```

### What did you expect to see?

I didn't expect to see any error when exiting the python interpreter.

### What did you see instead?

I saw error `PythonFinalizationError: cannot join thread at interpreter shutdown`

Make sure you include information that can help us debug (full error message, exception listing, stack trace, logs).

See [TROUBLESHOOTING.md](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/TROUBLESHOOTING.md) for how to diagnose problems better.

### Anything else we should know about your project / environment?

I was able to resolve this issue using another workaround

```diff
partheniou@partheniou-vm-3:~/git/grpc$ git diff src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/completion_queue.pyx.pxi
diff --git a/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/completion_queue.pyx.pxi b/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/completion_queue.pyx.pxi
index 56c67dcdea..69230e46dd 100644
--- a/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/completion_queue.pyx.pxi
+++ b/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/completion_queue.pyx.pxi
@@ -133,7 +133,13 @@ cdef class PollerCompletionQueue(BaseCompletionQueue):
         # TODO(https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/22365) perform graceful shutdown
         grpc_completion_queue_shutdown(self._cq)
         while not self._shutdown:
-            self._poller_thread.join(timeout=_POLL_AWAKE_INTERVAL_S)
+            try:
+                self._poller_thread.join(timeout=_POLL_AWAKE_INTERVAL_S)
+            except RuntimeError:
+                # At this point we can no longer join a thread because the interpreter
+                # is already shutting down.
+                # See https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/39520
+                pass
         grpc_completion_queue_destroy(self._cq)
```

```
partheniou@partheniou-vm-3:~/git/grpc$ python3.14
Python 3.14.0b1 (main, May  7 2025, 19:23:10) [GCC 14.2.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import grpc
>>> from grpc import aio
>>> print(grpc.__version__)
1.73.0.dev100 # this is my own debug version
>>> aio.secure_channel("http://localhost/", grpc.local_channel_credentials())
<grpc.aio._channel.Channel object at 0x7f31dfdcf770>
>>> exit
```

issue.title: fix: handle default aio loop deprecation warnings in Python 3.14

labels.name: release notes: no
labels.description: Indicates if PR should not be in release notes

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
This fix avoids:

- `RuntimeError`: In Python 3.14, `RuntimeError` is emitted if there is no current event loop when running `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()`

- `DeprecationWarning`: Warnings in this code block were treated as exceptions. 

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/e21fb6701eba9e55f33b427d82010b8f8ce857d7/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi#L187-L194

Since `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy()` is deprecated as of Python 3.14, we are receiving a new `DeprecationWarning` as an exception.

This change only silences `DeprecationWarning` for `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop()` but not for `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy().new_event_loop()`. We're also no longer treating/handling  `DeprecationWarning` as an exception.

Note that this approach is temporal, this logic should be migrated prior to official launch of Python 3.14.
See the bug which tracks the long term fix here: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/39518.

Fixes https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/39507

body:
With both https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/39523 and https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/39525, testing looks good for `Python 3.14.0b1`


```
partheniou@partheniou-vm-3:~/git/grpc$ python3.14
Python 3.14.0b1 (main, May  7 2025, 19:23:10) [GCC 14.2.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import grpc
>>> print(grpc.__version__)
1.73.0.dev0
>>> from grpc import aio
>>> aio.secure_channel("http://localhost/", grpc.local_channel_credentials())
<grpc.aio._channel.Channel object at 0x7ff13d3e06e0>
>>> exit
```

I don't think to suppressing `RuntimeError` when no aio loop is running (as proposed in #39523) is the right thing to do.

Note that in the reproduction case `aio.secure_channel("http://localhost/", grpc.local_channel_credentials())` is executed outside of an `async` function, which would normally be executed by a runner handling the event loop creation.

To work with awaitable objects in REPL, Python provides [asyncio REPL](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio.html#asyncio-cli).

An example without asyncio REPL:
```console
$ python3.14
Python 3.14.0b4 (main, Jul 12 2025, 00:59:52) [Clang 16.0.0 (clang-1600.0.26.6)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import asyncio
>>> await asyncio.sleep(1, result='hello')
  File "<python-input-1>", line 1
    await asyncio.sleep(1, result='hello')
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
SyntaxError: 'await' outside function
Try the asyncio REPL (python3.14 -m asyncio) to use top-level 'await' and run background asyncio tasks.
>>> asyncio.sleep(1, result='hello')
<coroutine object sleep at 0x109bf8040>
>>> exit
<sys>:0: RuntimeWarning: coroutine 'sleep' was never awaited
```

An example with asyncio REPL:
```console
$ python3.14 -m asyncio
asyncio REPL 3.14.0b4 (main, Jul 12 2025, 00:59:52) [Clang 16.0.0 (clang-1600.0.26.6)] on darwin
Use "await" directly instead of "asyncio.run()".
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import asyncio
>>> await asyncio.sleep(1, result='hello')
'hello'
>>> exit
exiting asyncio REPL...
```

Same examples using Python 3.11:

```console
$ python3.11
Python 3.11.13 (main, Jun  6 2025, 23:28:53) [Clang 16.0.0 (clang-1600.0.26.6)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import asyncio
>>> await asyncio.sleep(1, result='hello')
  File "<stdin>", line 1
SyntaxError: 'await' outside function
>>> asyncio.sleep(1, result='hello')
<coroutine object sleep at 0x104fd1540>
>>> exit
sys:1: RuntimeWarning: coroutine 'sleep' was never awaited
RuntimeWarning: Enable tracemalloc to get the object allocation traceback

$ python3.11 -m asyncio
asyncio REPL 3.11.13 (main, Jun  6 2025, 23:28:53) [Clang 16.0.0 (clang-1600.0.26.6)] on darwin
Use "await" directly instead of "asyncio.run()".
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import asyncio
>>> await asyncio.sleep(1, result='hello')
'hello'
>>> exit
exiting asyncio REPL...
```

That said, the gRPC Python team will consider what's the right way to handle the `RuntimeError: no running event loop`.  I think we  _at least_ should start displaying a deprecation warning when gRPC aio methods are executed outside of the event loop context.

Found some historical context for the current behavior (create loops on demand instead of RuntimeError): #23377.
We may have to preserve this approach after all. Will investigate further.

issue.title: [Python][Support 3.14] Enable 3.14 in Python Basic, Bazel and Distrib tests

labels.name: release notes: no
labels.description: Indicates if PR should not be in release notes

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
This PR enables Python 3.14 in all the different tests - Basic tests (Native Python tests), Bazel tests and Distrib tests to build Python 3.14 artifacts. In addition, it also updates all the public facing METADATA versions.

## Distribtests
Required pre-requisite changes to enable 3.14 artifacts are covered in #40289 .

## Bazel tests
Enabling Python 3.14 required updating the rules_python version to a more recent version that supports 3.14. This was done in #40602 

## Basic tests
The following errors were caught by the Basic tests when running via Python 3.14 and resolved in this PR:

### 1) No running event loop for AsyncIO when run outside an async function
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi", line 184, in grpc._cython.cygrpc.get_working_loop
RuntimeError: no running event loop
```
This was caught by the `tests_aio.unit.outside_init_test.TestOutsideInit` and `tests_aio.unit.init_test.TestInit` tests, and was also previously reported in #39507 with the root cause.

Following some investigation, the fix is being worked on by @sergiitk  in PR #40293. In order to parallelize the fix and this PR, these 2 tests are currently being skipped for Python 3.14 and above.

### 2) Pickling error from the `multiprocessing` library
```
_pickle.PicklingError: Can't pickle <function _test_well_known_types at 0x7f3937eee610>: it's not the same object as tests.unit._dynamic_stubs_test._test_well_known_types
when serializing dict item '_target'
when serializing multiprocessing.context.Process state
when serializing multiprocessing.context.Process object
```
This was caught by the `tests.unit._dynamic_stubs_test.DynamicStubTest` which runs test cases in a subprocess using the `multiprocessing` library.
Error root cause:
- The default start method of multiprocessing in linux has changed to `forkserver` instead of `fork` from Python 3.14.
- `forkserver` has a few extra restrictions for picklability as compared to `fork` (Ref: [Python Docs](https://docs.python.org/3.14/library/multiprocessing.html#the-spawn-and-forkserver-start-methods))
- All the [test case functions](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/0243842d5d10f624bf8f09f45026dd300805502f/src/python/grpcio_tests/tests/unit/_dynamic_stubs_test.py#L115) in the DynamicStubTest that are provided as `target` to the `multiprocessing.Process` use decorators. This causes problems when pickling them. 

Hence to resolve this, we manually set the 'start method' of `multiprocessing` to use the `fork` start method.

issue.title: [Backport][v1.75.x][Python][Support 3.14] Enable 3.14 supported wheels

labels.name: release notes: yes
labels.description: Indicates if PR needs to be in release notes

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
Backport of #40403 to v1.75.x.
---
This PR enables Python 3.14 in all the different tests - Basic tests (Native Python tests), Bazel tests and Distrib tests to build Python 3.14 artifacts. In addition, it also updates all the public facing METADATA versions.

## Distribtests
Required pre-requisite changes to enable 3.14 artifacts are covered in #40289 .

## Bazel tests
Enabling Python 3.14 required updating the rules_python version to a more recent version that supports 3.14. This was done in #40602 

## Basic tests
The following errors were caught by the Basic tests when running via Python 3.14 and resolved in this PR:

### 1) No running event loop for AsyncIO when run outside an async function
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi", line 184, in grpc._cython.cygrpc.get_working_loop
RuntimeError: no running event loop
```
This was caught by the `tests_aio.unit.outside_init_test.TestOutsideInit` and `tests_aio.unit.init_test.TestInit` tests, and was also previously reported in #39507 with the root cause.

Following some investigation, the fix is being worked on by @sergiitk  in PR #40293. In order to parallelize the fix and this PR, these 2 tests are currently being skipped for Python 3.14 and above.

### 2) Pickling error from the `multiprocessing` library
```
_pickle.PicklingError: Can't pickle <function _test_well_known_types at 0x7f3937eee610>: it's not the same object as tests.unit._dynamic_stubs_test._test_well_known_types
when serializing dict item '_target'
when serializing multiprocessing.context.Process state
when serializing multiprocessing.context.Process object
```
This was caught by the `tests.unit._dynamic_stubs_test.DynamicStubTest` which runs test cases in a subprocess using the `multiprocessing` library.
Error root cause:
- The default start method of multiprocessing in linux has changed to `forkserver` instead of `fork` from Python 3.14.
- `forkserver` has a few extra restrictions for picklability as compared to `fork` (Ref: [Python Docs](https://docs.python.org/3.14/library/multiprocessing.html#the-spawn-and-forkserver-start-methods))
- All the [test case functions](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/0243842d5d10f624bf8f09f45026dd300805502f/src/python/grpcio_tests/tests/unit/_dynamic_stubs_test.py#L115) in the DynamicStubTest that are provided as `target` to the `multiprocessing.Process` use decorators. This causes problems when pickling them. 

Hence to resolve this, we manually set the 'start method' of `multiprocessing` to use the `fork` start method.

issue.title: Python 3.14 support

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Python 3.14 is set to release in 2 weeks, there is currently a release candidate available. 
grpc is currently incompatible with Python 3.14. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
Please make a wheel compatible with Python 3.14.

issue.title: [Python][Cleanup] `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy()` will be removed in Python 3.16

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
`asyncio.get_event_loop_policy()` will be removed in Python 3.16. We need to remove usage of `asyncio.get_event_loop_policy()` which appears [here](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Agrpc%2Fgrpc%20get_event_loop_policy&type=code).

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/116820911e0a0775f3e1be92a6e0896d0c0d61d4/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/common.pyx.pxi#L177-L194

See https://docs.python.org/dev/whatsnew/3.14.html#deprecated

See https://docs.python.org/3.14/library/asyncio-policy.html and https://docs.python.org/dev/whatsnew/3.14.html#id6 for more information

As per the docs,

```
Deprecated since version 3.14: The get_event_loop_policy() function is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3.16.
```
